title: Quiz 1: Fundamentals of Community Health & Disease
description: Assessment covering core concepts, determinants of health, the epidemiologic triangle, and disease prevention levels.

questions.question: Which definition best describes 'Community Health' according to the study material?

options.text: Meeting the needs of a community by identifying problems and managing interactions within the community
The complete absence of disease or infirmity in a specific geographical region
A balanced state of well-being resulting from harmonious interactions of body, mind, and spirit
The statistical analysis of population density and cohort distribution

questions.explanation: Community health is defined as meeting the needs of a community by identifying problems and managing interactions within the community.
questions.hint: Focus on the management of interactions and problem identification.

questions.question: Which of the following are recognized as key determinants of health? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Determinants of health include economic, social, physical environmental, and biological/genetic factors.
questions.hint: Think about the broad categories that influence a person's well-being outside of just medical care.

questions.question: Match the component of the Epidemiologic Triangle with its correct description:

pairs.right: Extrinsic factors affecting opportunity for exposure

questions.explanation: The Agent is the cause, the Host is the organism harboring the disease, and the Environment is the external setting bringing them together.
questions.hint: One is the germ, one is the person, and one is the setting.

questions.question: Arrange the Chain of Infection in the correct sequence of transmission:

items.text: Agent moves through Portal of Exit
Agent is conveyed by Mode of Transmission
Agent enters through Portal of Entry

questions.explanation: Transmission sequence: Reservoir -> Portal of Exit -> Mode of Transmission -> Portal of Entry -> Susceptible Host.
questions.hint: Follow the path of the germ leaving one person and infecting another.

questions.question: Based on the table below regarding NCD Prevention Levels, which activity represents 'Secondary Prevention'?

richContent.content:
LevelTargetGoal
PrimaryHealthy PopulationPrevent occurrence
SecondaryPatient PopulationMinimize damage/Early diagnosis
TertiaryPatient PopulationRehabilitation

options.text: Screening tests to detect illness early

questions.explanation: Secondary prevention (disease control) attempts to minimize damage after disease has occurred but before it advances, such as screening. Immunization is Primary; Rehab is Tertiary.
questions.hint: Look at the 'Goal' column for Secondary prevention in the table.

questions.question: In the context of disease control, ___BLANK___ refers to the reduction of disease incidence to a locally acceptable level, while ___BLANK___ refers to the permanent reduction to zero of worldwide incidence.
questions.explanation: Control reduces disease to acceptable levels (e.g., diarrhea). Eradication reduces worldwide incidence to zero (e.g., smallpox).
questions.hint: One implies managing the disease; the other implies wiping it out completely.

questions.question: All microbes are germs that cause disease.
questions.explanation: Not all microbes are germs. Many are harmless or helpful (e.g., digesting food, decaying garbage). Only pathogens/germs cause disease.
questions.hint: Think about bacteria used in digestion or yogurt.

questions.question: Which of the following are classified as Non-Communicable Diseases (NCDs)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The 4 main types of NCDs are cardiovascular diseases, cancers, chronic respiratory diseases, and diabetes. TB is communicable.
questions.hint: Select the diseases that cannot be caught from another person.

questions.question: What is the term for a person without apparent disease who is capable of transmitting an infectious agent to others?
questions.explanation: A carrier is a person without apparent disease who is nonetheless capable of transmitting the agents to others (e.g., asymptomatic or incubatory carriers).
questions.hint: Starts with 'C'. They carry the germ but don't show symptoms.

questions.question: Which step of outbreak investigation involves characterizing the outbreak by time, place, and person?
questions.explanation: Descriptive epidemiology involves characterizing an outbreak by variables such as time, place, and person to develop hypotheses.
questions.hint: This step describes the 'who, when, and where' of the outbreak.
